text:
I’m quite late to this question but wanted to leave my answer anyways:

As a non-native English speaker working in content marketing, I understand where you’re coming from and I truly think this is one of the biggest issues currently affecting our career trajectory. Unfortunately, there’s a lot of bias and discrimination in hiring content marketers/writers, even if most of the times it’s not mentioned or spoken about.

An obvious example of this is the countless job ads that mark “Native English skills” as a requirement, even if language is a skill like any other and can be learned by anyone—no matter where you’re born. Personally, I’ve encountered this bias directly and indirectly many times, even being automatically disqualified from a job because I’m not a native speaker (I was told this was the reason by the recruiter).

I think as remote work is here to stay, we’ll only see this issue become more prominent. And this is affecting content people in particular (as opposed to, say, engineers) because there’s a wrong assumption that native English skills are what makes us good at our job.

I don’t really have advice for you but more so a reassurance that while it’s more difficult for us, it _is_ possible to advance in this career and be hired by bigger brands. Although fewer, there are people who understand what being great at content means and that where you’re born doesn’t impact your ability to be a great content writer. I’ve been hired by such people, and I, in turn, have hired non-native speakers as content writers.

But generally, I think this is a systematic issue that will have to be addressed at the organizational level to have any truly impactful change. For all the progress we’re making with D&I initiatives, I’d like to see more people in the content marketing take a stand against this type of discrimination and actively speak against the biases that we as a community still have when it comes to who can or can’t be a good content writer.
